holidays.name: New Year's Day
holidays.description: New Year's Day is the first day of the Gregorian calendar, which is widely used in many countries such as the USA.

holidays.name: World Braille Day
holidays.description: World Braille Day celebrates the life and achievements of Louis Braille, who invented the braille code for the visually impaired.

holidays.name: Epiphany
holidays.description: Many people in the United States annually observe Epiphany, or Three Kings’ Day, on January 6. It is a Christian observance and a public holiday in the US Virgin Islands.

holidays.name: Orthodox Christmas Day
holidays.description: Many Orthodox Christian churches in countries such as the United States observe Christmas Day on or near January 7 in the Gregorian calendar.

holidays.name: International Programmers' Day
holidays.description: Many people celebrate International Programmers’ Day on January 7, while others observe this event on the 256th day of the year, usually on September 13 or on September 12 in leap years.

holidays.name: Stephen Foster Memorial Day
holidays.description: Stephen Foster Memorial Day is annually observed in the United States on January 13. The day remembers the achievements of Stephen Foster, who is known as the “father of American music”.

holidays.name: Orthodox New Year
holidays.description: Many Orthodox Christian churches in countries such as the United States celebrate New Year’s Day on January 14 in the Gregorian calendar.

holidays.name: Lee-Jackson Day
holidays.description: Lee-Jackson Day is an annual state holiday in Virginia, the United States, on the Friday before Martin Luther King Day in January.

holidays.name: Robert E. Lee's Birthday
holidays.description: Robert E. Lee’s birthday is an annual official state holiday that is shared with Martin Luther King’s birthday in some parts of the US.

holidays.name: Confederate Heroes' Day
holidays.description: On Confederate Memorial Day remembers the soldiers who died fighting for the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War (1861-1865). It is a state holiday in some parts of the United States.

holidays.name: World Religion Day
holidays.description: World Religion Day fosters interfaith dialogue and understanding of all religions.

holidays.name: Tu Bishvat/Tu B'Shevat
holidays.description: Tu B’Shevat is known as the “New Year for Trees”, is a Jewish festival similar to Arbor Day.

holidays.name: Martin Luther King Jr. Day
holidays.description: Martin Luther King Day marks the anniversary of the date of birth of the influential American civil right leader of the same name.

holidays.name: Robert E. Lee's Birthday
holidays.description: Robert E. Lee’s birthday is an annual official state holiday that is shared with Martin Luther King’s birthday in some parts of the US.

holidays.name: Idaho Human Rights Day
holidays.description: Idaho Human Rights Day is a state holiday in Idaho, the United States, on the third Monday of January.

holidays.name: Civil Rights Day
holidays.description: Civil Rights Day is on the third Monday of January in Arizona and New Hampshire. It honors civil rights activists such as Martin Luther King Jr.

holidays.description: International Customs Day celebrates custom personnel and agencies worldwide.

holidays.name: International Day of Commemoration in Memory of the Victims of the Holocaust
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Day of Commemoration in Memory of the Victims of the Holocaust remembers those who died and suffered during the Holocaust before and during World War II. It is on January 27 each year.

holidays.description: World Leprosy Day brings awareness of leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, and ways to prevent the disease.

holidays.name: Kansas Day
holidays.description: Kansas Day is an annual observance that commemorates the state's admission to the Union in 1861.

holidays.name: National Freedom Day
holidays.description: National Freedom Day in the United States is observed on February 1 each year.

holidays.name: National Wear Red Day
holidays.description: National Wear Red Day® raises public awareness of heart disease in women and ways to avoid and combat this problem.

holidays.name: World Wetlands Day
holidays.description: World Wetlands Day raises awareness about the important role that the wetlands play in the environment and in our lives.

holidays.name: Groundhog Day
holidays.description: Many people in the United States observe Groundhog Day on February 2.

holidays.name: Super Bowl
holidays.description: The Super Bowl is the championship game of the National Football League (NFL) in the United States. It is played every year in February.

holidays.name: World Cancer Day
holidays.description: World Cancer Day is an annual global event on February 4 to raise people’s awareness of cancer.

holidays.name: Rosa Parks Day
holidays.description: The life of American civil rights leader Rosa Parks is celebrated in the United States on either February 4 or December 1.

holidays.name: Chinese New Year

holidays.name: International Day of Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation
holidays.description: The International Day of Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation is an awareness campaign to end a harmful practice that violates girls’ and women’s rights.

holidays.description: The International Day of Women and Girls in Science is a UN holiday to recognize the critical role women and girls play in science and technology communities.

holidays.name: World Day of the Sick
holidays.description: World Day of the Sick is a global event when people remember or pray for the sick.

holidays.name: Lincoln's Birthday
holidays.description: Lincoln’s Birthday is observed in the United States in honor of Abraham Lincoln, who was the nation’s 16th president and was known as the Great Emancipator.

holidays.description: World Radio Day is an annual United Nations (UN) event that promotes the importance of the radio in communicating information worldwide.

holidays.name: Valentine's Day
holidays.description: Valentine's Day is an occasion to celebrate romantic love.

holidays.description: Washington's Birthday, or Presidents' Day, honors the life and work of the first president of the United States, George Washington.

holidays.name: World Day of Social Justice
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) World Day of Social Justice promotes poverty eradication, full employment and social integration. It is on February 20 each year.

holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Mother Language Day is annually held on February 21 to celebrate languages spoken worldwide. It also observes the human right to use these languages.

holidays.name: Zero Discrimination Day
holidays.description: Discrimination Day highlights the negative impacts of discrimination and promotes tolerance, compassion and peace.

holidays.name: St. David's Day

holidays.name: Read Across America Day
holidays.description: Read Across America Day is observed in the United States on March 2 each year.

holidays.name: Employee Appreciation Day
holidays.description: Employee Appreciation Day is a US unofficial observance that recognizes and appreciates employees in all industries, aimed at helping employers keep their staff.

holidays.name: Texas Independence Day
holidays.description: Texas Independence Day is a legal holiday in Texas, in the United States.

holidays.name: World Wildlife Day
holidays.description: World Wildlife Day celebrates all flora and fauna, including animals, on Earth.

holidays.name: Casimir Pulaski Day
holidays.description: Casimir Pulaski Day is a day off for some schools and offices in Illinois, USA, on the first Monday of March each year.

holidays.description: Shrove Tuesday is traditionally known as the day prior to Lent but it also serves as a day of celebration, known as Mardi Gras.

holidays.description: The state of Vermont, in the USA, holds its Town Meeting Day on the first Tuesday of March each year.

holidays.name: Ash Wednesday
holidays.description: Ash Wednesday is a Christian observance that marks the first day of Lent, which is prior to Easter.

holidays.name: International Women's Day
holidays.description: International Women’s Day celebrates women’s achievements worldwide and throughout history.

holidays.name: World Kidney Day
holidays.description: World Kidney Day is an annual observation that attempts to raise global awareness about the importance of kidney health and tries to bring attention to the unique challenges faced by those who suffer from Chronic Kidney Disease.

holidays.name: St. Patrick's Day
holidays.description: St Patrick's Day marks the life and deeds of St Patrick, one of Ireland's patron saints. It is an Irish-American celebration in the USA.

holidays.description: Evacuation Day in Suffolk County, Massachusetts, commemorates the first major American military victory in the Revolutionary War, which saw the British troops evacuate Boston.

holidays.name: International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination is annually observed on March 21.

holidays.name: World Poetry Day
holidays.description: World Poetry Day celebrates poetry around the world on March 21 each year.

holidays.name: International Day of Nowruz

holidays.description: World Water Day aims to increase people's awareness of the water's importance in all aspects of life.

holidays.name: World Meteorological Day
holidays.description: World Meteorological Day marks the anniversary of the World Meteorological Organization's establishment on March 23, 1950.

holidays.description: World Tuberculosis Day is annually held on March 24 to raise awareness of tuberculosis and ways to eradicate the disease.

holidays.description: The International Day of Remembrance of the Victims of Slavery and the Transatlantic Slave Trade remembers the lives of Africans who were forced into slavery in North, Central and South America.

holidays.description: The UN’s International Day of Solidarity with Detained and Missing Staff Members is annually held on March 25.

holidays.description: National Vietnam War Veterans Day is an US observance to honor US military members who served during the Vietnam War.

holidays.name: Earth Hour

holidays.description: César Chávez Day celebrates the birthday of César Estrada Chávez.

holidays.description: World Autism Awareness Day raises an awareness of issues surrounding people, particularly children, with autism worldwide.

holidays.name: Pascua Florida Day
holidays.description: Pascua Florida Day, which usually falls on April 2, is a state day in Florida, USA.

holidays.description: Isra and Mi'raj (Isra Me'raj, Israa and Mi'raaj, Laylat Al-Isra wa Al-Miraj, Lailat al Miraj, Night Journey and Ascension to Heaven) marks the night when the Prophet Mohammad traveled from Mecca to Jerusalem, ascended to heaven and returned.

holidays.name: United Nations' Mine Awareness Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' International Day for Mine Awareness and Assistance in Mine Action is annually observed on April 4.

holidays.name: International Day of Sport for Development and Peace
holidays.description: The International Day of Sport for Development and Peace aims to bring goodwill and positive social outcomes through sporting achievements.

holidays.name: National Tartan Day
holidays.description: National Tartan Day is annually observed on April 6 to honor the major role that Scottish Americans played in the founding of the United States of America.

holidays.name: United Nations' World Health Day
holidays.description: The World Health Organization, the United Nations' the directing and coordinating authority for health, annually highlights one of its priorities for global health on World Health Day.

holidays.name: Day of Remembrance of the Victims of the Rwanda Genocide
holidays.description: The UN’s Day of Remembrance of the Victims of the Rwanda Genocide is observed on April 7 each year.

holidays.name: Palm Sunday

holidays.description: Father Damien Day or Saint Damien Day is an occasion for residents of the state of Hawaii to remember the life and deeds of a Belgian missionary.

holidays.name: Patriot's Day
holidays.description: Patriot's Day commemorates the battles of Lexington and Concord in 1775, which were two of the earliest battles in the American Revolutionary War.

holidays.description: Maundy Thursday, which is also known as Holy Thursday, is the day before Good Friday.

holidays.name: International Day for Monuments and Sites
holidays.description: The International Day for Monuments and Sites raises awareness on preserving and conserving historical and archeological heritage sites.

holidays.name: Easter Sunday

holidays.name: San Jacinto Day
holidays.description: San Jacinto Day commemorates the Battle of San Jacinto in what is now Harris County, Texas.

holidays.name: Earth Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' International Mother Earth Day promotes environmental awareness and calls for the protection of our planet.

holidays.name: English Language Day
holidays.description: English Language Day promotes the history, culture and accomplishments of the English language.

holidays.description: International Chernobyl Disaster Remembrance Day is a UN holiday designed to raise awareness of the consequences of the 1986 nuclear accident.

holidays.description: On Confederate Memorial Day remembers the soldiers who died fighting for the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War (1861-1865). It is a state holiday in some parts of the United States.

holidays.description: Loyalty Day is a special day for people to reaffirm their loyalty to the United States and to recognize the heritage of American freedom.

holidays.description: World Tuna Day is a UN holiday designed to raise awareness of the global importance of tuna.

holidays.name: National Day of Prayer
holidays.description: National Day of Prayer is held on the first Thursday of May each year, inviting Americans of all faiths to pray for the country and its leaders.

holidays.description: World Press Freedom Day focuses on the importance of the freedom of the press and freedom of expression.

holidays.description: Kent State Shootings Remembrance Day is a local observance in Kent, Ohio.

holidays.description: Rhode Island Independence Day is a day to celebrate the state's declaration of independence from Great Britain in 1776.

holidays.description: National Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) Day is an occasion to remember those serving the profession of explosive ordnance disposal in the United States Armed Forces.

holidays.description: 'Cinco de Mayo' means "Fifth of May" in Spanish and is a festival of Mexican pride and heritage.

holidays.description: Many Jewish communities in the United States celebrate Yom Ha’Atzmaut, which is Israel’s Independence Day, on the fifth day of the month of Iyar in the Jewish calendar.

holidays.description: On Confederate Memorial Day remembers the soldiers who died fighting for the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War (1861-1865). It is a state holiday in some parts of the United States.

holidays.description: Appreciate and thank all the military spouses and partners you know on Military Spouse Appreciation Day.

holidays.name: Mother's Day

holidays.name: International Day of Families
holidays.description: The International Day of Families is an occasion to celebrate the importance of families to people, societies and cultures around the world.

holidays.description: World Information Society Day is celebrated each year to raise awareness of how information and communication can be beneficial for societies and economies.

holidays.name: National Defense Transportation Day
holidays.description: National Defense Transportation Day occurs annually in the United States on the third Friday of May.

holidays.name: Armed Forces Day

holidays.name: Preakness Stakes
holidays.description: The Preakness Stakes is the second event in the Triple Crown and is annually held two weeks after the Kentucky Derby.

holidays.description: Vesak Day is a Buddhist holiday that celebrates the birth of its founder. It is usually observed on the day of the full moon in May.

holidays.description: The World Day for Cultural Diversity for Dialogue and Development, held on May 21, is an occasion for people to deepen their understanding of cultural diversity.

holidays.description: Emergency Medical Services for Children (EMSC) Day is observed on the Wednesday of Emergency Medical Services (EMS) Week, May 19–25, in the United States.

holidays.description: Harvey Milk Day is an observance that is recognized in public schools in California, United States, on May 22 each year.

holidays.name: Lag BaOmer
holidays.description: Many Jewish Americans observe Lag B’Omer on the 18th day of the month of Iyar in the Jewish calendar.

holidays.name: International Day to End Obstetric Fistula
holidays.description: The International Day to End Obstetric Fistula raises awareness of fistula and calls for support to tackle the problem.

holidays.name: African Liberation Day
holidays.description: African Liberation Day celebrates African nations' hard-fought freedom from European colonial powers.

holidays.name: National Missing Children's Day
holidays.description: National Missing Children's Day is an observation dedicated to addressing the problem of child abduction.

holidays.name: Memorial Day
holidays.description: Memorial Day commemorates all Americans who have died in military service for the United States.

holidays.name: Jefferson Davis' Birthday
holidays.description: Jefferson Davis' Birthday, also known as Jefferson Davis Day, is a state holiday in Alabama in the United States.

holidays.name: International Day of United Nations Peacekeepers
holidays.description: The International Day of United Nations Peacekeepers is an occasion to pay tribute to people who served in United Nations (UN) peacekeeping operations.

holidays.name: Ascension Day
holidays.description: Ascension Day is the 40th day of Easter and commemorates the ascension of Jesus Christ into heaven.

holidays.name: World No Tobacco Day
holidays.description: World No Tobacco Day draws attention to the health problems caused by tobacco use.

holidays.name: Lailat al-Qadr
holidays.description: Laylat al Qadr is most likely to be held on one of the last 10 days of month of Ramadan in the Islamic calendar.

holidays.name: Global Day of Parents
holidays.description: Global Day of Parents appreciates the role of a parent in nurturing and fostering growth for their children.

holidays.name: Statehood Day
holidays.description: Statehood Day marks the anniversary of the dates that Kentucky became the 15th state and Tennessee became the 16th state of the United States.

holidays.name: Jefferson Davis' Birthday
holidays.description: Jefferson Davis' Birthday, also known as Jefferson Davis Day, is a state holiday in Alabama in the United States.

holidays.name: Jefferson Davis' Birthday
holidays.description: Jefferson Davis' Birthday, also known as Jefferson Davis Day, is a state holiday in Alabama in the United States.

holidays.name: Eid al-Fitr
holidays.description: Eid al-Fitr, which is on the first day of the Islamic month of Shawwal, marks the end of the month-long fast of Ramadan.

holidays.name: International Day of Innocent Children Victims of Aggression
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Day of Innocent Children Victims of Aggression is observed on June 4 each year.

holidays.name: World Environment Day
holidays.description: World Environment Day is held each year on June 5. It is one of the principal vehicles through which the United Nations (UN) stimulates worldwide awareness of the environment and enhances political attention and action.

holidays.name: D-Day
holidays.description: D-Day is a special anniversary in some countries, including the United States (U.S.), to remember Allied forces’ invasion of Normandy, France, in the Second World War.

holidays.name: World Oceans Day
holidays.description: World Oceans Day is annually observed on June 8 to raise awareness of the challenges humanity faces to protect the world's oceans.

holidays.name: Belmont Stakes
holidays.description: The Belmont Stakes is the third and final horse race of the Triple Crown. It is run annually five weeks after the Kentucky Derby.

holidays.name: Pentecost
holidays.description: Many Christians in the United States observe Pentecost, also known as Whitsunday or Whit Sunday.

holidays.name: Shavuot
holidays.description: Shavuot, also known as the Festival of Weeks, is one of three major Jewish festivals.

holidays.name: Whit Monday
holidays.description: Many Christians in the United States will observe Whit Monday, or Pentecost Monday. It is the day after Pentecost, which is also known as Whit Sunday or Whitsunday.

holidays.name: Kamehameha Day
holidays.description: Kamehameha Day, held annually on June 11, honors Kamehameha the Great (Kamehameha I), the monarch who united and established the Kingdom of Hawaii.

holidays.name: World Day Against Child Labour
holidays.description: Poverty and injustice against widows is a world-wide problem addressed by International Widows' Day.

holidays.name: International Albinism Awareness Day
holidays.description: International Albinism Awareness Day aims to stop the persecution and murders of people with albinism.

holidays.name: World Blood Donor Day
holidays.description: On World Blood Donor Day numerous events are held worldwide to raise awareness about the importance of safe blood supplies.

holidays.name: Flag Day
holidays.description: Flag Day is annually held on June 14 to honor the United States flag.

holidays.name: World Elder Abuse Awareness Day
holidays.description: World Elder Abuse Awareness Day attempts to shine a light on the problem of physical, emotional, and financial abuse of elders.

holidays.name: Trinity Sunday
holidays.description: Trinity Sunday is the first Sunday after Pentecost and is celebrated by many Christians in the United States.

holidays.name: International Day of Family Remittances
holidays.description: The UN estimates that family remittances worth over 500 billion US$ are transferred worldwide every year.

holidays.name: Father's Day
holidays.description: Father's Day celebrates the contribution that fathers and father figures make to the lives of their children.

holidays.name: Bunker Hill Day
holidays.description: Bunker Hill Day commemorates the Battle of Bunker Hill, which took place on June 17, 1775 on the Charlestown Peninsula, Boston Harbor, in Massachusetts.

holidays.name: World Day to Combat Desertification and Drought
holidays.description: The United Nations' World Day to Combat Desertification and Drought is observed worldwide on June 17 each year.

holidays.name: International Day for the Elimination of Sexual Violence in Conflict
holidays.description: International Day for the Elimination of Sexual Violence in Conflict is a UN day aiming to rid the world of conflict-related sexual violence.

holidays.name: Juneteenth
holidays.description: Juneteenth, also known as Freedom Day and Emancipation Day, is a holiday or observance in many US states to celebrate the anniversary of the abolition of slavery in Texas on June 19, 1865.
holidays.locations: All except HI, MD, MT, NH, ND, MP, SD, TX, UT

holidays.name: Emancipation Day
holidays.description: Juneteenth, also known as Freedom Day and Emancipation Day, is a holiday or observance in many US states to celebrate the anniversary of the abolition of slavery in Texas on June 19, 1865.

holidays.name: World Refugee Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' World Refugee Day honors refugees' courage, strength and determination.

holidays.name: West Virginia Day
holidays.description: West Virginia Day, or WV Day, celebrates the anniversary of the creation of the state of West Virginia on June 20, 1863.

holidays.name: American Eagle Day
holidays.description: Observed annually on June 20 in 47 American states, American Eagle Day is an unofficial holiday that celebrates the removal of the American Bald Eagle from a list of "endangered species".

holidays.name: International Day of Yoga
holidays.description: The International Day of Yoga is a UN-day that aims to raise awareness worldwide of the many benefits of practicing yoga.

holidays.name: Corpus Christi
holidays.description: Corpus Christi is observed in honor of the Holy Eucharist.

holidays.name: Public Service Day
holidays.description: The United Nations’ Public Service Day celebrates the idea that democracy and successful governance depend on a competent civil service.

holidays.name: International Widows' Day
holidays.description: Poverty and injustice against widows is a world-wide problem addressed by International Widows' Day.

holidays.name: Day of the Seafarer
holidays.description: The Day of the Seafarer aims to acknowledge the social, and economic contribution of the millions of seafarers around the world.

holidays.name: International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking raise awareness about the dangers of illicit drugs.

holidays.name: International Day in Support of Victims of Torture
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day in Support of Victims of Torture is annually observed on June 26 to remind people that human torture is not only unacceptable – it is also a crime.

holidays.name: International Asteroid Day
holidays.description: The United Nations established International Asteroid Day to raise public awareness of the asteroid impact hazard.

holidays.name: Independence Day
holidays.description: On Independence Day, Americans celebrate the anniversary of publication of the Declaration of Independence from Great Britain in 1776.

holidays.name: International Day of Cooperatives
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Day of Cooperatives recognizes and reaffirms the role of cooperatives in economic, social and cultural development and in the achievement of social policy objectives.

holidays.name: World Population Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) World Population Day reaffirms the human right to plan for a family.

holidays.name: World Youth Skills Day
holidays.description: Acquiring skills enhances youths' ability to make informed choices and empowers them to gain access to changing labor markets.

holidays.name: Nelson Mandela Day
holidays.description: Nelson Mandela International Day is annually observed on July 18 to recognize the former South African president’s contribution to peace and freedom.

holidays.name: Pioneer Day
holidays.description: Pioneer Day is an annual state holiday in Utah in the United States. It is celebrated to honor the pioneers who demonstrated industry and bravery when they ventured to settle in a place that is now Salt Lake City.

holidays.name: National Korean War Veterans Armistice Day
World Hepatitis Day
holidays.description: World Hepatitis Day is observed on July 28 every year to raise awareness of hepatitis and encourage prevention and treatment.

holidays.name: Parents' Day
holidays.description: Parents’ Day is celebrated in the United States on the fourth Sunday of July each year to recognize and promote parenting as a crucial part of families and the wider community.

holidays.name: International Day of Friendship
holidays.description: The International Day of Friendship is annually held on July 30 to celebrate friendships worldwide.

holidays.name: World Day against Trafficking in Persons
holidays.description: July 30 is the UN World Day against Trafficking in Persons

holidays.name: Colorado Day
holidays.description: Colorado Day is an annual observance that commemorates the state’s birthday on August 1, 1876, and its history.

holidays.name: Purple Heart Day
holidays.description: Purple Heart Day on August 7 commemorates the day in 1782 when General George Washington created the Purple Heart Medal – a military decoration that is awarded to those wounded or killed while serving in the United States Armed Forces.

holidays.name: International Day of the World's Indigenous People
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day of the World's Indigenous People is observed on August 9 each year to promote and protect the rights of the world’s indigenous peoples.

holidays.name: Tisha B'Av
holidays.description: Tisha B’Av is on the ninth day of the month of Av in the Jewish calendar.

holidays.name: Eid al-Adha
holidays.description: Eid-al-Adha is an Islamic festival to mark Ibrahim's willingness to follow Allah's command to sacrifice his son. It is celebrated around the 10th to 13th days of the Islamic month of Dhu al-Hijjah.

holidays.name: International Youth Day
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Youth Day is annually held on August 12 to celebrate the achievements of the world’s youth and to encourage their participation in enhancing society.

holidays.name: Victory Day
holidays.description: Victory Day, also known as VJ Day, is an annual state holiday celebrated on the second Monday in August in Rhode Island in the United States. It marks the anniversary of the Allies’ victory over Japan during World War II.

holidays.name: Assumption of Mary
holidays.description: Assumption Day is a Christian observance in the United States that is held annually on August 15. Catholics observe the Dormition (falling asleep) or the day that the Blessed Virgin Mary was received into heaven.

holidays.name: Statehood Day in Hawaii
holidays.description: Hawaii’s Statehood Day is celebrated on the third Friday of August to commemorate the anniversary of Hawaii’s statehood.

holidays.name: Bennington Battle Day
holidays.description: Bennington Battle Day is a state holiday in Vermont. It commemorates the American victory at the Battle of Bennington during the Revolutionary War in north America in 1777.

holidays.name: World Humanitarian Day
holidays.description: The United Nations’(UN) World Humanitarian Day focuses on increasing public awareness about humanitarian service worldwide and is annually observed on August 19.

holidays.name: National Aviation Day
holidays.description: National Aviation Day is observed in the United States on August 19 each year to celebrate the history and development of the aviation.

holidays.name: Senior Citizens Day
holidays.description: National Senior Citizens Day is an observance on August 21 to honor the contributions of senior citizens in the United States.

holidays.name: International Day for the Remembrance of the Slave Trade and its Abolition
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day for the Remembrance of the Slave Trade and its Abolition is held on August 23 each year to remind people of the tragedy of the transatlantic slave trade.

holidays.name: Women's Equality Day
holidays.description: Women's Equality Day on August 26 is an annual observance that commemorates the anniversary of the first time voting rights were extended to women in the United States.

holidays.name: Lyndon Baines Johnson Day
holidays.description: Lyndon Baines Johnson Day is a state holiday in Texas in the United States on August 27 each year. It commemorates the birthday of Lyndon Baines Johnson, who was the 36th president of the USA.

holidays.name: International Day against Nuclear Tests
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day against Nuclear Tests is annually observed on August 29. The day raises awareness of the dangers of nuclear weapons and a closer approach to eliminating the use of those weapons.

holidays.name: International Day of the Victims of Enforced Disappearances
holidays.description: The International Day of the Victims of Enforced Disappearances is annually observed on August 30.

holidays.name: Muharram
holidays.description: The first day of Muharram, which is the first month in the Islamic calendar, marks the start of the Islamic New Year.

holidays.name: International Overdose Awareness Day
holidays.description: International Overdose Awareness Day is an annual observation which aims to raise global awareness of about the impact of drug overdose on families and communities. The campaign also attempts to remove the stigma associated with overdose.

holidays.name: Labor Day
holidays.description: Labor Day is a federal holiday in the United States. It gives workers a day of rest and it celebrates their contribution to the American economy.

holidays.name: World Sexual Health Day
holidays.description: World Sexual Health Day is an annual awareness day that attempts to break down social and cultural taboos associated with sexuality and to promote sexual health around the world.

holidays.name: International Day of Charity
holidays.description: The International Day of Charity raises public awareness of what charities do to help minimize poverty.

holidays.name: Carl Garner Federal Lands Cleanup Day
holidays.description: Carl Garner Federal Lands Cleanup Day encourages people in the United States to participate in cleaning up the federal lands. It is observed on the first Saturday after Labor Day.

holidays.name: International Literacy Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Literacy Day is held on September 8 each year.

holidays.name: National Grandparents Day
holidays.description: National Grandparents Day is celebrated on the first Sunday of September after Labor Day in the United States.

holidays.name: California Admission Day
holidays.description: California Admission Day is an annual legal observance in California, in the United States.

holidays.name: World Suicide Prevention Day
holidays.description: World Suicide Prevention Day promotes worldwide action to prevent suicides on September 10 each year.

holidays.name: Patriot Day
holidays.description: Patriot Day is held in memory of nearly 3000 people who died during terrorist attacks in New York, Washington DC and Shanksville, Pennsylvania, in the United States.

holidays.name: International Day for South-South Cooperation
holidays.description: The United Nations Day for South-South Cooperation is observed on September 12 each year.

holidays.name: International Programmers' Day
holidays.description: Many people celebrate International Programmers’ Day on January 7, while others observe this event on the 256th day of the year, usually on September 13 or on September 12 in leap years.

holidays.name: Friday the 13th
holidays.description: Friday the 13th is a day full of superstitious beliefs in communities worldwide.

holidays.name: International Day of Democracy
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day of Democracy is observed on September 15 each year.

holidays.name: International Day for the Preservation of the Ozone Layer
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Day for the Preservation of the Ozone Layer focuses on the importance of protecting human health and the environment.

holidays.name: Constitution Day and Citizenship Day
holidays.description: Constitution Day and Citizenship Day is a combined event that occurs in the United States on September 17 each year.

holidays.name: National POW/MIA Recognition Day
holidays.description: National POW/MIA Recognition Day is annually observed in the United States on the third Friday of September.

holidays.name: International Day of Peace
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Day of Peace is annually held on September 21 to recognize the efforts of individuals, organizations and governments to end conflict and promote peace.

holidays.name: Emancipation Day
holidays.description: Emancipation Day is a state-wide observation in Ohio on September 22.

holidays.name: International Celebrate Bisexuality Day
holidays.description: International Celebrate Bisexuality Day, also known as Bi Visibility Day, promotes the rights of bisexual people around the world.

holidays.name: World Maritime Day
holidays.description: World Maritime Day is held on the last week of September each year, although the exact date is up to individual governments around the world.

holidays.name: International Day for the Total Elimination of Nuclear Weapons
holidays.description: The International Day for the Total Elimination of Nuclear Weapons raises awareness about the dangers of nuclear weapons.

holidays.name: World Tourism Day
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) World Tourism Day is annually held on September 27 to raise awareness on the benefits of tourism.

holidays.name: Native American Day
holidays.description: Native Americans' Day is celebrated in the state of South Dakota, while Indigenous People's Day is celebrated in Berkeley, California, on the second Monday of October.

holidays.name: World Rabies Day
holidays.description: World Rabies Day is annually observed on September 28 to raise awareness about rabies and how it can be prevented.

holidays.name: World Heart Day
holidays.description: World Heart Day raises awareness of cardiovascular diseases and ways to reduce their risk.

holidays.name: Gold Star Mother's Day
holidays.description: Gold Star Mother’s Day is annually observed in the United States on the last Sunday of September.

holidays.name: Rosh Hashana
holidays.description: Rosh Hashana, also spelled Rosh Hashanah, is commonly known as the Jewish New Year. The event begins on the first day of Tishrei (or Tishri), which is the seventh month in the Jewish calendar.

holidays.name: Rosh Hashana
holidays.description: Rosh Hashana, also spelled Rosh Hashanah, is commonly known as the Jewish New Year. The event begins on the first day of Tishrei (or Tishri), which is the seventh month in the Jewish calendar.

holidays.name: International Day of Older Persons
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Day of Older Persons is celebrated on October 1 each year as a special day for older persons worldwide.

holidays.name: World Vegetarian Day
holidays.description: World Vegetarian Day is an annual observation that spreads awareness about the health, environmental, and ethical benefits of following a vegetarian lifestyle. The unofficial holiday encourages people to avoid eating foods that include animal products and to adopt a plant-based diet.

holidays.name: International Day of Non-Violence
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day of Non-Violence is a globally observed on October 2 each year to promote non-violence.

holidays.name: World Cerebral Palsy Day
holidays.description: World Cerebral Palsy Day is an annual awareness observation that brings together people with cerebral palsy, their families and loved ones, and organizations working to ensure equal rights for them.

holidays.name: Feast of St Francis of Assisi
holidays.description: Many Catholics in the United States, particularly those with pets, celebrate the Feast of St Francis of Assisi, the patron saint of animals and the environment, on October 4 each year.

holidays.name: World Teachers' Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) World Teachers' Day commemorates the work of teachers and their contributions to society. It is observed on October 5 each year.

holidays.name: World Habitat Day
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) World Habitat Day reflects on the state of human settlements and people’s right to sufficient shelter.

holidays.name: Child Health Day
holidays.description: Child Health Day is annually celebrated in the United States on the first Monday of October.

holidays.name: World Post Day
holidays.description: World Post Day marks the anniversary of the Universal Postal Union's establishment in 1874. It is held on October 9 each year.

holidays.name: International Day for Natural Disaster Reduction
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day for Natural Disaster Reduction is annually observed on the second Wednesday of October to promote a global culture of natural disaster risk reduction.

holidays.name: Leif Erikson Day
holidays.description: Leif Erikson Day honors the first Scandinavian known to have set foot on American soil and the contribution of the Nordic peoples to the United States.

holidays.name: Yom Kippur
holidays.description: Yom Kippur is an important Jewish holiday that falls on the 10th day of the month of Tishrei in the Jewish calendar.

holidays.name: Yom Kippur
holidays.description: Yom Kippur is an important Jewish holiday that falls on the 10th day of the month of Tishrei in the Jewish calendar.

holidays.name: World Mental Health Day
holidays.description: World Mental Health Day, which is supported by the United Nations (UN), is annually held on October 10 to raise public awareness about mental health issues worldwide.

holidays.name: World Sight Day
holidays.description: World Sight Day is annually held on the second Thursday of October to raise awareness about blindness and vision impairment.

holidays.name: International Day of the Girl Child
holidays.description: The International Day of the Girl Child is a United Nations (UN) observance on October 11 each year.

holidays.name: Navy Birthday
holidays.description: Navy Birthday celebrates the establishment of the United States Navy on October 13, 1775.

holidays.name: Chicago Marathon
holidays.description: The Chicago Marathon is one of the six World Marathon Majors and is held annually in October.

holidays.name: First Day of Sukkot
holidays.description: The first day of Sukkot marks the start of the Sukkot festival for Jewish communities in many countries, including the United States.

holidays.name: Columbus Day
holidays.description: Columbus Day celebrates 15th century explorer Christopher Columbus's arrival in America in 1492.
holidays.locations: All except AK, AR, CA, DE, FL, HI, MI, MN, NV, ND, OR, SD, TX, VT, WA, WY

holidays.name: Columbus Day
holidays.description: Columbus Day celebrates 15th century explorer Christopher Columbus's arrival in America in 1492.

holidays.name: Native Americans' Day
holidays.description: Native Americans' Day is celebrated in the state of South Dakota, while Indigenous People's Day is celebrated in Berkeley, California, on the second Monday of October.

holidays.name: Indigenous People's Day
holidays.description: Native Americans' Day is celebrated in the state of South Dakota, while Indigenous People's Day is celebrated in Berkeley, California, on the second Monday of October.

holidays.name: International Day of Rural Women
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day of Rural Women is annually celebrated on October 15 to recognize rural women’s role in supporting their communities.

holidays.name: White Cane Safety Day
holidays.description: White Cane Safety Day is a United States observance annually held on October 15 to celebrate blind and visually impaired people's achievements and the importance of the white cane.

holidays.name: World Food Day
holidays.description: World Food Day is celebrated on October 16 each year.

holidays.name: Boss's Day
holidays.description: Boss’s Day is observed in many workplaces in the United States on October 16, or the nearest working day, each year.

holidays.name: International Day for the Eradication of Poverty
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day for the Eradication of Poverty is annually observed on October 17 to promote awareness of the need to eradicate poverty worldwide.

holidays.name: Alaska Day
holidays.description: Alaska Day is an official holiday in Alaska, the United States, on October 18 each year. It commemorates the formal transfer of Alaska from Russia to the United States on October 18, 1867.

holidays.name: Last Day of Sukkot
holidays.description: Many Jewish communities in countries such as the United States observe the last day of Sukkot, which marks the end of the Sukkot festival.

holidays.name: Shmini Atzeret
holidays.description: Shemini Atzeret (or Shmini Atzeret) is a Jewish holiday dedicated to the love of God, while Simchat Torah (Simchas Torah or Simhat Torah) marks the end of Sukkot and celebrates the completion of the annual reading of the Torah.

holidays.name: Simchat Torah
holidays.description: Simchat Torah (Simchas Torah or Simhat Torah) is a Jewish holiday that marks the end of Sukkot and celebrates the completion of the annual reading of the Torah.

holidays.name: United Nations Day
holidays.description: United Nations Day marks the anniversary of the United Nations Charter coming into force in 1945 and celebrates the work of this organization. United Nations Day annually falls on October 24.

holidays.name: World Development Information Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) World Development Information Day falls on October 24 each year.

holidays.name: Nevada Day
holidays.description: Nevada Day is an annual state holiday celebrated in Nevada, the United States, on the last Friday of October. It commemorates the statehood of Nevada, which took place on October 31, 1864.

holidays.name: World Day for Audiovisual Heritage
holidays.description: The World Day for Audiovisual Heritage is observed on October 27 every year.

holidays.name: Diwali/Deepavali
holidays.description: Diwali, also known as the Festival of Lights, marks the beginning of the Hindu New Year.

holidays.name: World Stroke Day
holidays.description: World Stroke Day is annually held on October 29 to raise awareness about stroke and ways to combat it.

holidays.name: World Cities Day
holidays.description: World Cities Day is a UN observance that aims to recognize the role of cities as  a foundation for social and economic development.

holidays.name: Halloween
holidays.description: Halloween is celebrated by hosting costume parties, playing 'trick-or-treat', watching horror films, visiting haunted houses or carving lanterns out of pumpkins.

holidays.name: All Saints' Day
holidays.description: Many Catholics honor all the saints on All Saints' Day, also known as All Hallows' Day, in the United States.

holidays.name: World Vegan Day
holidays.description: World Vegan Day is an annual observation that brings together vegans around the world to bring attention to animal rights and to spread the word about the health advantages of following a vegan diet.

holidays.name: All Souls' Day
holidays.description: Prayers for the dead are made on All Souls’ Day in the United States, which falls on November 2 each year. The Day of the Dead is also celebrated on this day.

holidays.name: International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists
holidays.description: The International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists raises awareness about violence against journalists.

holidays.name: New York City Marathon
holidays.description: The New York City Marathon is one of the world's largest marathons and takes place every year in November.

holidays.name: International Day for Preventing the Exploitation of the Environment in War and Armed Conflict
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day for Preventing the Exploitation of the Environment in War and Armed Conflict is held on November 6 each year.

holidays.name: The Prophet's Birthday
holidays.description: Eid Milad ul-Nabi (Mawlid or Milad-un-Nabi) commemorates the Prophet Muhammed's birthday.

holidays.name: World Science Day for Peace and Development
holidays.description: The World Science Day for Peace and Development (WSDPD) is celebrated on November 10 each year.

holidays.name: Marine Corps Birthday
holidays.description: Marine Corps Birthday celebrates the establishment of the United States Marine Corps on November 10, 1775.

holidays.name: Veterans Day
holidays.description: Veterans Day in the USA is a holiday to honor all who have served in the United States Military Services.

holidays.name: World Pneumonia Day
holidays.description: World Pneumonia Day supports all efforts made to protect and treat people against pneumonia, the single largest cause of child deaths worldwide.

holidays.name: World Diabetes Day
holidays.description: World Diabetes Day is held annually to raise awareness of diabetes and its complications and the care that people with this condition need. It is observed on November 14 each year.

holidays.name: International Day for Tolerance
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day for Tolerance is observed on November 16 each year to help people understand the importance of tolerance worldwide.

holidays.name: World Day of Remembrance for Road Traffic Victims
holidays.description: The World Day of Remembrance for Road Traffic Victims serves as a major advocacy day for road traffic injury prevention.

holidays.name: World Prematurity Day
holidays.description: World Prematurity Day is an annual observance that is dedicated to raising awareness about the health and emotional issues surrounding preterm birth.

holidays.name: World Toilet Day
holidays.description: World Toilet Day aims to promote public awareness of the need for adequate toilets to improve people’s health and save lives.

holidays.name: International Men's Day
holidays.description: International Men’s Day celebrates men's achievements worldwide and throughout history.

holidays.name: Universal Children's Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) Universal Children's Day is an occasion to promote the welfare of children and an understanding between children all over the world. It is held on November 20 each year

holidays.name: Africa Industrialization Day
holidays.description: Africa Industrialization Day aims to stimulate the international community's commitment to the industrialization of Africa.

holidays.name: World Television Day
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) World Television Day is globally celebrated on November 21 each year.

holidays.name: World Philosophy Day
holidays.description: World Philosophy Day is celebrated on the third Thursday of November each year.

holidays.name: International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women raises public awareness of violence against women in all countries around the world and at all levels of society. It is observed each year on November 25.

holidays.name: Thanksgiving Day
holidays.description: Thanksgiving Day in the United States is traditionally a holiday to give thanks for the food collected at the end of the harvest season.

holidays.name: International Day of Solidarity with the Palestinian People
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day of Solidarity with the Palestinian People is annually observed on November 29.

holidays.name: State Holiday
holidays.description: Robert E. Lee’s birthday is an annual official state holiday that is shared with Martin Luther King’s birthday in some parts of the US.

holidays.name: Presidents' Day
holidays.description: Washington's Birthday, or Presidents' Day, honors the life and work of the first president of the United States, George Washington.

holidays.name: Lincoln's Birthday/Lincoln's Day
holidays.description: Lincoln’s Birthday is observed in the United States in honor of Abraham Lincoln, who was the nation’s 16th president and was known as the Great Emancipator.

holidays.name: Day After Thanksgiving
holidays.description: The Day After Thanksgiving, also known as Black Friday, is a state holiday more than 20 states.

holidays.name: Day After Thanksgiving
holidays.description: The Day After Thanksgiving, also known as Black Friday, is a state holiday more than 20 states.

holidays.name: Family Day
holidays.description: The Day After Thanksgiving, also known as Black Friday, is a state holiday more than 20 states.

holidays.name: Acadian Day
holidays.description: The Day After Thanksgiving, also known as Black Friday, is a state holiday more than 20 states.

holidays.name: Black Friday
holidays.description: Black Friday is the day after Thanksgiving Day in the USA. It is a busy shopping day and is a holiday in some states.

holidays.name: American Indian Heritage Day
holidays.description: American Indian Heritage Day is observed on the Friday after Thanksgiving Day in the United States.

holidays.name: First Sunday of Advent
holidays.description: Many Christians in the United States observe the first Sunday of Advent, which marks the start of the Christian year.

holidays.name: World AIDS Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) World AIDS Day is annually observed on December 1.

holidays.name: Rosa Parks Day
holidays.description: The life of American civil rights leader Rosa Parks is celebrated in the United States on either February 4 or December 1.

holidays.name: Rosa Parks Day
holidays.description: The life of American civil rights leader Rosa Parks is celebrated in the United States on either February 4 or December 1.

holidays.name: International Day for the Abolition of Slavery
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Day for the Abolition of Slavery is annually observed on December 2.

holidays.name: Cyber Monday
holidays.description: Most online retailers in the US offer discounted prices on their products and services on Cyber Monday.

holidays.name: International Day of Persons with Disabilities
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Day of Persons with Disabilities is annually observed on December 3 to re-affirm and draw attention to the rights of people who live with disabilities.

holidays.name: International Volunteer Day for Economic and Social Development
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Volunteer Day for Economic and Social Development, also known as International Volunteer Day (IVD), is observed on December 5 each year.

holidays.name: World Soil Day
holidays.description: World Soil Day raises awareness of why soil is needed for sustainable living.

holidays.name: St Nicholas Day
holidays.description: Some churches in the United States recognize St Nicholas' Day as a feast day.

holidays.name: International Civil Aviation Day
holidays.description: International Civil Aviation Day is observed globally on December 7 each year. It is observed by organizations such as the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).

holidays.name: Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day
holidays.description: National Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day remembers those who died or were injured when Pearl Harbor, in Hawaii, was attacked in 1941.

holidays.name: Feast of the Immaculate Conception
holidays.description: The Feast of the Immaculate Conception is a Christian observance on December 8 each year.

holidays.name: International Anti-Corruption Day
holidays.description: The United Nations’ (UN) International Anti-Corruption Day is annually observed on December 9 to raise public awareness of corruption and ways to fight it.

holidays.name: World Genocide Commemoration Day
holidays.description: World Genocide Commemoration Day is a UN holiday dedicated to the victims of genocide.

holidays.name: Human Rights Day
holidays.description: Human Rights Day marks the anniversary of when the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was proclaimed.

holidays.name: International Mountain Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Mountain Day is an occasion to help raise awareness of the people who live in mountainous regions and the role that these regions play in providing food, water, and recreation. It is observed on December 11 each year.

holidays.name: Feast of Our Lady of Guadalupe
holidays.description: The Feast of Our Lady Guadalupe, in honor of Jesus’ mother Mary, is a Catholic observance in the United States.

holidays.name: Friday the 13th
holidays.description: Friday the 13th is a day full of superstitious beliefs in communities worldwide.

holidays.name: Pan American Aviation Day
holidays.description: December 17 marks Pan American Aviation Day, which is annually observed in the United States.

holidays.name: Wright Brothers Day
holidays.description: The Wright Brothers Day is annually celebrated in the United States on December 17 to commemorate the historic flight made by Orville and Wilbur Wright on that date in 1903.

holidays.name: International Migrants Day
holidays.description: The United Nations (UN) International Migrants Day is celebrated on December 18 each year.

holidays.name: Arabic Language Day
holidays.description: World Arabic Language Day is a United Nations (UN) observance that celebrates one of the organization’s 6 official languages – Arabic.

holidays.name: International Human Solidarity Day
holidays.description: The United Nations' (UN) International Human Solidarity Day is celebrated on December 20 each year to raise public awareness on the importance of solidarity in fighting poverty.

holidays.name: Chanukah/Hanukkah (first day)
holidays.description: The first day of Hanukkah is the start of the Hanukkah period, which lasts for eight days, from the 25th day of the month of Kislev to the second day of Tevet in the Hebrew calendar.

holidays.name: Christmas Eve
holidays.description: Christmas Eve in the United States is on December 24 each year.
holidays.locations: MI, KS (partly), NC, ND, OK, SC, TX, WI, VA (partly)

holidays.name: Christmas Eve
holidays.description: Christmas Eve in the United States is on December 24 each year.

holidays.name: Washington's Birthday
holidays.description: Washington's Birthday, or Presidents' Day, honors the life and work of the first president of the United States, George Washington.

holidays.name: Christmas Day
holidays.description: Christmas Day celebrates Jesus Christ's birth.

holidays.name: Kwanzaa (first day)
holidays.description: Kwanzaa is a week-long holiday honoring the culture and traditions of African people and their descendants worldwide, especially in the United States.

holidays.name: Day After Christmas Day
holidays.description: Some states in the United States observe the Day after Christmas Day as a public holiday.

holidays.name: Day After Christmas Day
holidays.description: Some states in the United States observe the Day after Christmas Day as a public holiday.

holidays.name: Last Day of Chanukah
holidays.description: The last day of Hanukkah marks the end of a festive Jewish occasion, known as Hanukkah or Chanukah.

holidays.name: New Year's Eve
holidays.description: New Year's Eve is the last day of the year in the Gregorian calendar. Many parties to welcome the New Year are held in in the United States on New Year's Eve.

holidays.name: New Year's Eve
holidays.description: New Year's Eve is the last day of the year in the Gregorian calendar. Many parties to welcome the New Year are held in in the United States on New Year's Eve.
